Wiley's UI Living Style Guide

Introduction

Wiley’s UI Living Style Guide is an accessory to the One Wiley Brand Guidelines. The purpose of this style guide is to help inform the design of digital products such as websites, web apps, and mobile apps. Like the One Wiley Brand Guidelines, this living style guide is meant to be flexible, and it will evolve over time. The intention is that UI designers start using it as much as possible over time, so please check back here when starting a new digital initiative.

Currently the toolkit only includes some fundamental elements of the One Wiley visual language and several footer templates. In the future we aim to increase the scope of the One Wiley UI Guidelines to encompass a wide range of HTML and CSS components that can be easily dropped into future websites and applications.

View the One Wiley Brand Guidelines
Read about the One Wiley Brand
Contractors: If you are unable to access the One Wiley Brand Guidelines using the links above, please consult with an internal contact at Wiley.

How to use these guidelines

These guidelines have been designed to ensure we have a consistent, yet flexible brand look and feel across all of Wiley. They’ve been divided into nine key sections that should provide a good understanding of what to do and how to do it.

While we’ve provided many examples, there will always be some exceptions to the rules or questions that remain unanswered. If you find yourself in such a situation, then do your best to come to a sensible conclusion. If there’s something that you’re not 100% sure about, then please feel free to contact a member of the UI Living Style Guide team.

Our brand architecture

Wiley has a direct relationship with an increasing amount of products and brands. Some are sub-brands of Wiley, others communicate their own identity to a particular user group.

To illustrate the broad range of distinct online products Wiley helps facilitate, we have created the diagram below.

  • Corporate Brand

    The Wiley Corporate Brand appears when communicating the business as a whole, rather than a specific service or product.

    Some examples include:

    • wiley.com
    • Building signage
    • Business cards
  • Core business and internal activities

    The Wiley Core business and internal activities exist as entities but they are not customer-facing. They may implement the One Wiley Visual Language where possible.

    Some examples include:

    • Wiley Portal
    • Global Brand Committee
    • Talent Solutions
  • Wiley subjects

    Subjects are a cross-business grouping of products within a single category. They are a way to collate and communicate publications and services in a cohesive manner while simultaneously expressing the One Wiley Visual Language.

    Some examples include:

    • Psychology
    • Architecture
    • Health
  • Wiley brand

    The brand and trade name under which work is published. Publishers may use brands to market a group of publications or content to a specific audience or identity a specific genre. A brand is more than a name. It needs to have unique associations, awareness, and equity. Brands are owned by Wiley and not businesses or corporations.

    Some examples include:

    • Dummies
    • Capstone
    • Sybex
  • Series

    Similar to Subjects, a series is a sequence of publications that have certain characteristics or an organizational theme in common.

    Some examples include:

    • Wiley Visualizing
    • Wiley Graphic Standards
    • Building Codes Illustrated
  • Wiley products and services

    A good that satisfies a set of requirements to meet the needs of a particular user group. Products and services can adopt their own Brand or be a part of an established Wiley or Partnership brand.

    Some examples include:

    • Wiley Online Library
    • Wiley Health Learning
    • WileyPLUS
  • Partnership

    An arrangement between different organizations or publishers whereby both parties agree to cooperate to advance their mutual interest. Partnerships differ from brands in that Wiley does not have full ownership of the partner’s brand.

    Some examples include:

    • Cochrane Library
    • Wiley IEEE
    • AGU and other societies

Contact us about these guidelines

The effort to maintain this living style guide is currently being undertaken by Stuart Allen .
